3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (13:30): itemref seems upside-down to me, if you took a section out of context, you may lose the itemref link and the name/value pair loses meaning or becomes part of another item
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (13:31): itemfor at least tells you it doesn't belong there, even if you don't know the whole story
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:31): seems the problems exist in both directions
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:33): Require the syntax to indicate the link in both directions, then it's harder to unknowingly break
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (13:33): I think itemref breaks more than itemfor
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (13:34): as it could add data to an item that shouldn't be there
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (13:34): I like the idea of articles being completely extractable, independent of their surroundings

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:35): the problem with itemfor="" is that it's a performance nightmare -- given an item, you have no choice but to walk the entire DOM to find if there are any more properties

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:38): If you're extracting all the items from a document, that's not a problem, because you have to walk the DOM anyway and you can keep track of itemfors while you're doing it
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:38): so it only seems a problem when you're trying to extract microdata from a specific element on the page
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:39): doesn't know how the use cases typically would be extracting data
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:41): wonders if querySelector('*[itemfor]') would be unreasonably slow anyway
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (13:42): there are use cases?! :)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:45): the DOM API would be a case where you're trying to extract microdata from a specific element on the page
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:45): and it happens to be a case where performance is critical
